SORN Network¶

The following methods are available via SORN

x(array) – Array of activity vectors of excitatory population y(array) – Array of activity vectors of inhibitory population

  • ti_min (float) –

  • te_max (float) –

  • ti_max (float) –

Returns

te(vector) – Threshold values for excitatory units ti(vector) – Threshold values for inhibitory units

static initialize_weight_matrix(network_type, synaptic_connection, self_connection, lambd_w)[source]

Args:

network_type(str) - Spare or Dense synaptic_connection(str) - EE,EI,IE: Note that Spare connection is defined only for EE connections self_connection(str) - True or False: i–>i ; Network is tested only using j–>i lambd_w(int) - Average number of incoming and outgoing connections per neuron

Returns: weight_matrix(array) - Array of connection strengths

lambda_ee = 20
lambda_ei = 40
lambda_ie = 100
mu_ip = 0.1
ne = 200
network_type_ee = 'Sparse'
network_type_ei = 'Sparse'
network_type_ie = 'Dense'
ni = 40
nu = 10
sigma_ip = 0.0
te_max = 1.0
te_min = 0.0
ti_max = 0.5
ti_min = 0.0

Plasticity¶

The following methods are available via sorn.Plasticity

class sorn.sorn.Plasticity[source]

Instance of class Sorn. Inherits the variables and functions defined in class Sorn Encapsulates all plasticity mechanisms mentioned in the article

static initialize_plasticity()[source]

NOTE: DO NOT TRANSPOSE THE WEIGHT MATRIX WEI FOR SORN 2 MODEL

ip(te, x)[source]
istdp(wei, x, y, cutoff_weights)[source]
static reorganize_network()[source]
ss(wee_t)[source]

Synaptic Scaling or Synaptic Normalization

stdp(wee, x, cutoff_weights)[source]

Apply STDP rule : Regulates synaptic strength between the pre(Xj) and post(Xi) synaptic neurons

static structural_plasticity(wee)[source]

Add new connection value to the smallest weight between excitatory units randomly

Statistics and Analysis¶

The following methods are available via utils.Statistics

class sorn.utils.Statistics[source]
static autocorr(firing_rates, t=2)[source]

Score interpretation:

scores near 1 imply a smoothly varying series scores near 0 imply that there’s no overall linear relationship between a data point and the following one

(that is, plot(x[-length(x)],x[-1]) won’t give a scatter plot with any apparent linearity)

scores near -1 suggest that the series is jagged in a particular way: if one point is above the mean, the next

is likely to be below the mean by about the same amount, and vice versa.

static avg_corr_coeff(spike_train)[source]
static fanofactor(spike_train, neuron, window_size)[source]

Investigate whether neuronal spike generation is a poisson process
